subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Quickscript Unicode Proposal
msgSnippet: I m afraid I have to disagree, The problems with ascii hacks is that they only kind of work most of the time. Ikonboard is a good example actually, topic
messageBody:
I'm afraid I have to disagree,

The problems with ascii hacks is that they only kind of work most of the
time.

Ikonboard is a good example actually, topic titles can't be in acsii
quikscript since it is displayed in the title bar which uses the system
font.
If I use a quikscript font as my system font any non-quikscript programs
will have gibberish and vise versa.
If I want to copy and paste from ikonboard to notepad I have the same
problem.
If I don't have the right font installed it doesn't fall back on another
quikscript font, it falls back on times new roman.

If I use a text terminal (I do btw :-) I have to use either 100% latin
or 100% quikscript.
Don't even think of using acsii quikscript with text to speech.

The advantage of unicode is that the computer can tell the difference
between an 'a' and '' and can do intelligent things because of it.

Sorry to rant (I don't mean to) - but ascii hacks are too like the whole
charset/codepage mess for my taste. :)

Michael Everson wrote:
> Well, the thing is...
>
> Nobody's using Shavian already, and that was encoded.
> http://www.shavian.org/hugh/ikonboard/ikonboard.cgi gives fonts which
> are ASCII hacks. And it does the same for QuickScript, which might
> for instance use Private Use codes. So.... you'll need a stronger
> case I think.
>
> And why isn't it a font variant of Shavian, or a variant with extensions?
> --
> Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com
>
>
